column1: In mathematics, and more specifically in graph theory, a [1] is a graph which is permitted to have multiple edges, that is, edges that have the same end nodes.
In mathematics, a [1] is a generalization of a graph in which an edge can join any number of vertices.

The adjacency matrix of a graph should be distinguished from its incidence matrix, a different matrix representation whose elements indicate whether vertex-edge pairs are incident or not, and its degree matrix, which contains information about the degree of each vertex.
 What does incident mean?
column2: a vertex is incident with an edge if the vertex is one of the two vertices the edge connects

column1: In mathematics and computer science, [1] is one of the basic concepts of graph theory: it asks for the minimum number of elements (nodes or edges) that need to be removed to separate the remaining nodes into two or more isolated subgraphs.
column5: It is closely related to the theory of network flow problems. The connectivity of a graph is an important measure of its resilience as a network.

column1: A directed graph is called [1] connected if replacing all of its directed edges with undirected edges produces a connected (undirected) graph.
column5: It is unilaterally connected or unilateral (also called semiconnected) if it contains a directed path from u to v or a directed path from v to u for every pair of vertices u, v. It is strongly connected, or simply strong, if it contains a directed path from u to v and a directed path from v to u for every pair of vertices u, v.
